00001 #ifndef _arp

00004 #include <functional>
00005 #include <unordered_map>
00006 // Note: Looks like "hash_map" is deprecated and we're supposed to use "unordered_map" now.
00007 // However, unordered_map is not yet part of standard C++, so that's not ideal, either.-------
00008 //
00009 // TODO: Maybe consider using the Boost library for a hash map implementation?
00010 // (How about waiting to see if the Boost library can be helpful in other parts of the project first.
00011 // Until then, it might not be worth complicating the project by having additional dependencies.)
00012 //
00013 // -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00014 //
00015 // I did some research on how to obtain a usable hash map implementation in C++.  Here is a
00016 // summary of my findings:
00017 //
00018 // The C++ Standard Library does not have a hash map implementation yet, but the upcoming
00019 // C++0x standard will define an unordered_map class.  At the time of this writing [June 2010],
00020 // C++0x is expected to be published by the end of 2011.
00021 //
00022 // For now, there are a couple options for obtaining a usable hash map implementation.  We
00023 // can:
00024 //
00025 // Use the older SGI STL extensions, or
00026 // Use the unofficial implementations of unordered_map, or
00027 // use the Boost library (or something similar).
00028 //
00029 //
00030 // Option 1: Use the older SGI STL extensions
00031 // --------------------------------------
00032 //
00033 // In newer GCC versions:
00034 // #include <ext/hash_map> and use __gnu_cxx::hash_map
00035 //
00036 // In older GCC versions:
00037 // #include <hash_map> and use hash_map.
00038 //
00039 // In MSVC:
00040 // #include <hash_map> and use stdext::hash_map.
00041 //
00042 // Note that there may be minor differences between these.  For this reason, this is not the
00043 // recommended approach for getting a usable hash map implementation.
00044 //
00045 //
00046 // Option 2: Use the unofficial implementations of unordered_map
00047 // -------------------------------------------------------------
00048 //
00049 // #include <unordered_map>, then use std::unordered_map.
00050 //
00051 // In GCC, you must enable one of the following compiler options:
00052 // -std=c++0x or -std=gnu++0x
00053 //
00054 // Haven't tested in MSVC! Based on this:
00055 // http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb982522.aspx
00056 // it should just work, but I haven't tried it.  Note that you might have to use
00057 // std::tr1::unordered_map instead.
00058 //
00059 // The C++ Technical Report 1 (TR1), published in 2005, proposes the unordered_map header and
00060 // data type.  The newer versions of some compilers (including GCC and MSVC) ship with
00061 // implementations of these proposed types, so it is possible to use unordered_map already.
00062 // (Technically, since TR1 has not yet been integrated into C++0x, doing so means you are
00063 // using non-standard code, but in theory, no changes should be necessary once it is standardized.)
00064 // However, compilers need not include TR1 to be conforming, so these implementations may be
00065 // missing in some toolchains.
00066 //
00067 // When compiling code that includes <ext/hash_map> (as per Option 1 above) in GCC,
00068 // a message generated from backward_warning.h recommends switching to <unordered_map>.
00069 //
00070 //
00071 // Option 3: Use the Boost library
00072 // -------------------------------
00073 //
00074 // Download boost, #include <boost/unordered_map.hpp>, and use boost::unordered_map.
00075 //
00076 // The advantage is that we will not have to use the dated SGI STL extensions (which isn't
00077 // recommended), nor the non-standard TR1 implementations that some compilers may or may not ship
00078 // with.  Furthermore, the Boost library provides a large number of other useful data types.
00079 //
00080 // The disadvantage is that having an additional dependency can complicate Minet unnecessarily,
00081 // especially if we use it for just a single data type.
00082 //
00083

00108  public:

00110

00158     }

00193 struct eqipaddress {
00194     bool operator()(const IPAddress lhs, const IPAddress rhs) const { 
00195         return (lhs == rhs);
00196     }
00197 };

00199 struct hashipaddress : public std::hash<unsigned> {
00200     std::hash<unsigned> H;
00201 
00202     size_t operator()(const IPAddress &x) const { 
00203         return H((unsigned)x); 
00204     }
00205 };
